text: To better understand how magma crystallizes , let us consider how a simple crystalline solid melts .
Thus , melting converts a solid consisting of tight , uniformly packed ions into a liquid composed of unordered ions moving randomly about .
Recall that , in any crystalline solid , the ions are arranged in a closely packed regular pattern .
Thus , heating causes the ions to occupy more space , which in turn causes the solid to expand .
When they are cooled sufficiently , the forces of the chemical bonds will again confine the ions to an orderly crystalline arrangement .
At this stage , the ions are able to slide past one another , and the orderly crystalline structure disintegrates .
When the ions are vibrating rapidly enough to overcome the force of their chemical bonds , melting occurs .
As the temperature rises , ions vibrate more rapidly and consequently collide with ever-increasing vigor with their neighbors .
As the temperature of the liquid drops , ions pack more closely together as their rate of movement slows .
In the process called crystallization , cooling reverses the events of melting .

When a magma body cools , the silicon and oxygen atoms link together first to form silicon-oxygen tetrahedra , the basic building blocks of the silicate minerals ( see crystallize at depth or at Earth ’s surface .
However , they are not without some motion ; they exhibit a restricted vibration about fixed points .
